author: @michaelkhan3
text: Here is what i did to use my own model:  I used a nodejs package that easily allows you to host a folder in your computer in a localhost server. https://www.npmjs.com/package/static-server  once you have it installed you just need to go the folder where you have all your files in the terminal and run the 'static-server' command. Then just change the loadModel line to use your local server E.g. model =  await tf.loadModel('http://localhost:9080/tfjsmodel/model.json');   You should then be able to hit your server on http://localhost:9080/pongai.html

author: @hyphenmusic8931
text: Hey Sentdex, the way you'd tackle the problem with loading the model is by using local server. I use *webpack-dev-server* and *webpack* to bundle js code (tensorflow and main.js) into single file and load through the index.html by accessing *localhost:8080/index.html* . Thus the model is available to the script from *localhost:8080/model.json* .  Btw: Love your work. If you struggle with js in future while working on new series or in general, I encourage you to ask me at *hyphen.wrex@**gmail.com*

author: @vincevannoort8115
text: Hey Sentdex,  I wanted to elaborate on the issue you were dealing with not being able to load the model.json locally. The issue is that it is a browser safety feature, it protects you from sites just being able to read any file from your computer.  An easy fix would be to just run a simple web server with python ('python3 -m http.server') or by an extension for sublime text 3 or visual studio code. If you do this, everyone should be able to reference the file locally with just 'model = await tf.loadModel('model.json');'.After setting up the webserver, you should no longer have that problem.  If you need futher explanation, just write me a message.

author: @StanleyYip011
text: sentdex the tensorflow master

As of the problem with hosting the model separately: you are serving the script over *'file://'* (clicking the index.html file and 'running it with a browser') protocol instead of *'http://'* .   It won't work as *'file://'* is not a *HyperlinkedTextTransferProtocol* , hyperlinked being important part here :D. A handy trick using *python* to quickly serve static content is, using your terminal, going to the directory of a *index.html* and running:  # this is in your linux shell or windows CMD $ python -m http.server 8080  where *8080* is the port. Then you can specify a relative path to your *.json* file, no need to use any external hosting.
